Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The Impacts of Service on Engineering Students (ISES) - A Longitudinal Study

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
This engineering education research project will increase our understanding of learning through service (LTS) programs, specifically aiming to determine whether international service learning is a viable curricular approach with respect to developing desired engineering attributes. The research questions addressed in the proposal are timely since an increasing number of engineering students participate in international service projects at some personal and institutional expense. The project hypothesizes that LTS improves holistic thinking without detracting from technical ability, and this hypothesis is tested through as well-defined set of research questions.

The broader significance and importance of this project is to validate service learning as an effective educational strategy for engineering students. Although such programs are popular, they can potentially add costs to college education and some questions about their effectiveness remain unanswered. This study may develop insights into LTS, and a set of "best practices" that can inform programs that wish to adopt this pedagogy. There is the potential to demonstrate improved recruitment and retention of under-represented groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Impacts of Service on Engineering Students (ISES) project, a collaboration between researchers at Michigan Tech and Tufts University, aimed to evaluate how attributes of future engineers are obtained through Learning Through Service (LTS, a catch-all term including service learning, community engagement, humanitarian engineering, etc.) and how these attributes develop over the time of undergraduate education. LTS has become a major force in engineering programs throughout the nation over the past decade in particular, and anecdotal evidence shared by faculty and student participants suggest it may be positively influencing motivation, retention, and education of engineering students.

 

The goals of the three year long project were to:

1.) recruit a group of engineering students willing to participate over the duration of this study

2.) gather a body of quantitative evidence through surveying the student participants twice annually for three years, and

3.) gather a body of qualitative evidence through interviewing a portion of the student participants twice annually for three years

4.) finalize the dataset for future exploration, and testing of the hypotheses above

 

This study collected data over a three year period in order to begin resolving these observational hypotheses, by following 266 engineering students throughout the period. The evaluation consisted of a three-year study of engineering students at four different universities that have engineering programs and a fifth cohort comprised of Engineers Without Borders-USA participants, one of the nation’s leading engineering service organizations. Participants shared the impacts of LTS on their technical attributes (like knowledge and skills), as well as a mix of personal attributes (like motivation, and well-being). Nearly 1000 surveys (more than 170,000 data points) and 600 interviews were collected over this three year investigation.

 

The large dataset required significant data processing and management time to ready it for detailed exploration in the future. Findings to date suggest that about one-fifth of engineering students become less involved in service activities with time over their studies, and approximately half do not change their amount of service. However, almost half of the students who start highly engaged become even more so with time – universities can be incubators for the engaged engineer. The ultimate contribution from this project is the database itself – open to other researchers, it may provide many investigators years of study into the education of engineering students, yielding better designed curricula and learning experiences, as well as engineers more responsive to the needs of society and industry.
